elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Three complexes of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (MPC) including [Hg(MPC)Cl2] (1), [Cd(MPC)3][CdBr4] (2) and a coordination polymer, {K[Cr(PDC)2]} n  (3) were prepared and identified by elemental analysis, FT-IR, Raman, 1H NMR spectroscopies and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. All coordination modes of MPC derivatives were studied by CSD and then optimized by DFT. A new formula for determination of geometry around the metals with coordination number four is presented.

<ce:section-title id="st100">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">In this work, three complexes, [Hg(MPC)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd(MPC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][CdBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and the coordination polymer, {K[Cr(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (MPC) and hydrolyzed MPC, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PDC), were prepared and identified by elemental analysis, FT-IR, Raman, <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectroscopy and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. All coordination modes of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate derivatives were studied by CSD to predict the behavior of MPC in reactions with metals. Subsequently, these coordination modes were optimized by DFT methods to determine of the most stable mode and charge distribution. In the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the mercury atom has a HgNO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> environment and inclines to a trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The molecule of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has two cadmium atoms with different geometries. One Cd atom has coordination number four and ideal tetrahedral geometry which is determined by using a new formula proposed in this paper. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> revealed a rare 2D <ce:italic>s</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>d</ce:italic> mixed-metal coordination polymer containing dodecahedrally coordinated potassium(I) and octahedral chromium(III). Common coordination number for mercury(II), cadmium(II) and chromium(III) is determined by studying of all complexes of them in CSD.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

In this work, three complexes, [Hg(MPC)Cl2] (1), [Cd(MPC)3][CdBr4] (2) and the coordination polymer, {K[Cr(PDC)2]} n  (3) of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (MPC) and hydrolyzed MPC, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC), were prepared and identified by elemental analysis, FT-IR, Raman, 1H NMR spectroscopy and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. All coordination modes of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate derivatives were studied by CSD to predict the behavior of MPC in reactions with metals. Subsequently, these coordination modes were optimized by DFT methods to determine of the most stable mode and charge distribution. In the crystal structure of 1, the mercury atom has a HgNO2Cl2 environment and inclines to a trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The molecule of 2 has two cadmium atoms with different geometries. One Cd atom has coordination number four and ideal tetrahedral geometry which is determined by using a new formula proposed in this paper. The crystal structure of 3 revealed a rare 2D s-d mixed-metal coordination polymer containing dodecahedrally coordinated potassium(I) and octahedral chromium(III). Common coordination number for mercury(II), cadmium(II) and chromium(III) is determined by studying of all complexes of them in CSD.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Dialkyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylates are present in the structure of variety of compounds including cryptands , cyclic polyethers , pyridine diester spacers , triple-helical complexes  and macrocyclic ionophores . These compounds are versatile ligands for erbium luminescence sensitization . The fluxional behavior  and pseudopolymorphism  for some of them were investigated by dynamic NMR spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT), respectively. Self-assembly of these compounds is due to <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions between pyridine rings .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Dialkyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylates are present in the structure of variety of compounds including cryptands , cyclic polyethers , pyridine diester spacers , triple-helical complexes  and macrocyclic ionophores . These compounds are versatile ligands for erbium luminescence sensitization . The fluxional behavior  and pseudopolymorphism  for some of them were investigated by dynamic NMR spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT), respectively. Self-assembly of these compounds is due to π-π interactions between pyridine rings .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Recently, we have extended our studies to metal complexes of dialkylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylates  and now focused on the coordination chemistry of dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (C<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, MPC, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>) by structural and theoretical studies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have extended our studies to metal complexes of dialkylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylates  and now focused on the coordination chemistry of dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (C9H9NO4, MPC,  ) by structural and theoretical studies.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate is a potentially pentadentate ligand binding to a metal through one N atom of the pyridine ring and the four O atoms of the carboxylate groups. Due to geometrical restrictions however, the donor atoms cannot coordinate to a metal center simultaneously. Examination of the Cambridge structural database (CSD)  revealed, that the coordination chemistry of compounds containing a dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate unit have not been investigated much. To introduce this type of ligands for coordination chemists, all reported structures containing a dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate unit are collected in the “” and all coordination modes are summarized in . This ligand can acts as NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-, NOO′-, NO′<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-, NO- and N-donor (O: oxygen atom of carbonyl group, O′: oxygen atom of ester group). The data reveals that the nitrogen atom participates in all coordination modes. In addition, the coordination probability of carbonyl oxygen atoms is higher than that of the ether group. The energies of each coordination mode were calculated by DFT methods and compared in theoretical section (see below). In all CSD searches discussed here, structures containing errors or disorder have been omitted.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate is a potentially pentadentate ligand binding to a metal through one N atom of the pyridine ring and the four O atoms of the carboxylate groups. Due to geometrical restrictions however, the donor atoms cannot coordinate to a metal center simultaneously. Examination of the Cambridge structural database (CSD)  revealed, that the coordination chemistry of compounds containing a dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate unit have not been investigated much. To introduce this type of ligands for coordination chemists, all reported structures containing a dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate unit are collected in the "" and all coordination modes are summarized in . This ligand can acts as NO2-, NOO'-, NO'2-, NO- and N-donor (O: oxygen atom of carbonyl group, O': oxygen atom of ester group). The data reveals that the nitrogen atom participates in all coordination modes. In addition, the coordination probability of carbonyl oxygen atoms is higher than that of the ether group. The energies of each coordination mode were calculated by DFT methods and compared in theoretical section (see below). In all CSD searches discussed here, structures containing errors or disorder have been omitted.

We also present a new formula for the determination of geometry around a metal with coordination number four.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, the preparation, characterization, crystal structures and theoretical studies of the complexes, [Hg(MPC)Cl2] (1), [Cd(MPC)3][CdBr4] (2) and the coordination polymer, {K[Cr(PDC)2]} n  (3), with dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (MPC) and pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) are described. H2PDC was formed as hydrolysis product of MPC during the complexation reactions . We also present a new formula for the determination of geometry around a metal with coordination number four.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Materials and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">All chemicals and solvents were reagent or analytical grade from commercial sources and used as received. The MPC ligand and K<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Cr(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] were prepared according to literature procedures . Infrared spectra (as KBr pellets) in the range of 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> were recorded with a FT-IR 8400-Shimadzu spectrometer. Raman spectra were performed using a Nicolet Model 910 Fourier-transform spectrometer. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra were recorded using a Bruker Avance 300 instrument; chemical shifts <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> are given in parts per million, relative to TMS as an internal standard. The melting points were determined with a Barnsted Electrothermal 9200 electrically heated apparatus.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and instrumentation

All chemicals and solvents were reagent or analytical grade from commercial sources and used as received. The MPC ligand and K3[Cr(O2)4] were prepared according to literature procedures . Infrared spectra (as KBr pellets) in the range of 4000-400cm-1 were recorded with a FT-IR 8400-Shimadzu spectrometer. Raman spectra were performed using a Nicolet Model 910 Fourier-transform spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded using a Bruker Avance 300 instrument; chemical shifts δ are given in parts per million, relative to TMS as an internal standard. The carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen contents were determined with a Thermo Finnigan Flash Elemental Analyzer 1112 EA. The melting points were determined with a Barnsted Electrothermal 9200 electrically heated apparatus.

0.19g (1.00mmol) of MPC dissolved in EtOH (10mL), was added with stirring to a solution of 0.27g (1.00mmol) of HgCl2 in EtOH (20mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 60°C for 5h. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3078m (ν CHar), 2947m (ν CH), 1724 s (ν CO), 1578m (ν CN), 1435m (δ as CH3), 1312 s (δ s CH3), 1257 v (ν CO), 748m and 694m (γ py). The crystals were kept at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K during data collection. Using OLEX-II , the structures were solved with the <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>

 refinement package using least squares minimisation. The molecular graphics were drawn with ORTEP-III , Mercury  and Diamond . Crystallographic data and details of the data collection and structure refinement are listed in

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination and refinement

Suitable crystals of 1 and 2 were selected on a Xcalibur Eos Gemini Ultra and 3 on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini Ultra diffractometers. The crystals were kept at 150K during data collection. Using OLEX-II , the structures were solved with the shelxs  structure solution program using Direct Methods and refined with the shelxl  refinement package using least squares minimisation. The molecular graphics were drawn with ORTEP-III , Mercury  and Diamond . Crystallographic data and details of the data collection and structure refinement are listed in  , selected bond lengths and angles in   and hydrogen bond geometries in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st040">Computational details</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The ground state geometries of all coordination modes were optimized with the Gaussian 09 software  and calculated in the gas phase using DFT  at the B3LYP/DGTZVP level of theory for Cd(II), Zn(II) and Cr(III) and B3LYP/SDD for Hg(II).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Computational details

The ground state geometries of all coordination modes were optimized with the Gaussian 09 software  and calculated in the gas phase using DFT  at the B3LYP/DGTZVP level of theory for Cd(II), Zn(II) and Cr(III) and B3LYP/SDD for Hg(II).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st045">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The reaction between MPC and a solution of mercury(II) chloride or cadmium(II) bromide formes complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. The coordination polymer <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was prepared by the reaction of potassium tetraperoxochromate(V) with MPC in a mixture of ethanol and water. During the reaction, MPC is hydrolyzed to dipicolinic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PDC) and chromium(V) is reduced to chromium(III). The complexes are air-stable and soluble in DMF and DMSO.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The reaction between MPC and a solution of mercury(II) chloride or cadmium(II) bromide formes complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The coordination polymer 3 was prepared by the reaction of potassium tetraperoxochromate(V) with MPC in a mixture of ethanol and water. During the reaction, MPC is hydrolyzed to dipicolinic acid (H2PDC) and chromium(V) is reduced to chromium(III). The complexes are air-stable and soluble in DMF and DMSO.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st050">Spectroscopic characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">In the IR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and ligand there is a band above 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which was assigned to vibrations of <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic> (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O). The <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic> (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) in the IR spectra of complexes is shifted about 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to lower energy whilst the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic> (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N) is shifted in range of 6–46<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to higher energy than those of the free ligand, indicating coordination through the carbonyl oxygen atom and nitrogen atom of pyridine ring, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic characterization

In the IR spectra of 1-3 and ligand there is a band above 1700cm-1, which was assigned to vibrations of ν (CO). The ν (CO) in the IR spectra of complexes is shifted about 20cm-1 to lower energy whilst the ν (CN) is shifted in range of 6-46cm-1 to higher energy than those of the free ligand, indicating coordination through the carbonyl oxygen atom and nitrogen atom of pyridine ring, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In the Raman spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, stretching vibrations of the metal–ligand bonds appear in the region of 100–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
. The M<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N, M<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and M<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>X (X: Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) stretching vibrations were assigned to the bands in the range of 460–620, 300–460 and 130–240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively which are in consistent with values reported in the literature .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the Raman spectra of 1-3, stretching vibrations of the metal-ligand bonds appear in the region of 100-600cm-1 . The MN, MO and MX (X: Cl-, Br-) stretching vibrations were assigned to the bands in the range of 460-620, 300-460 and 130-240cm-1, respectively which are in consistent with values reported in the literature .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In the <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> there are two sets of signals in region near 4 and above 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm which were assigned to protons of the OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> moiety and the pyridine ring, respectively. A signal due to the methoxy groups is split into a doublet due to their inequivalence.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the 1H NMR spectra of 1 and 2 there are two sets of signals in region near 4 and above 8ppm which were assigned to protons of the OCH3 moiety and the pyridine ring, respectively. A signal due to the methoxy groups is split into a doublet due to their inequivalence.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st055">Theoretical studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">All coordination modes of ligands containing dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate unit were obtained from CSD data (A, A′, B, C and D, ) then atomic coordinates of each mode with cadmium atom were optimized using Density Functional Theory (DFT) to determine total energy, charge distribution patterns and HOMO and LUMO orbitals (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0025"></ce:float-anchor>). In addition to these coordination modes, three other possible modes for 1:1 M:L stoichiometry (B′, E and F) which have not been observed, also were optimized (). The result revealed that the thermodynamic stability of all modes is very similar. The percentage of coordination modes in  is consistent with this observation. The charge distribution patterns of the coordination modes proved that the charges on nitrogen and oxygen atoms of the ligand became more negative upon coordination. In all coordination modes, the LUMO is delocalized over the whole of ligand except nitrogen atom and methyl groups while the HOMO is delocalized on the metal center without any significant participation of the ligand molecule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical studies

All coordination modes of ligands containing dimethylpyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate unit were obtained from CSD data (A, A', B, C and D, ) then atomic coordinates of each mode with cadmium atom were optimized using Density Functional Theory (DFT) to determine total energy, charge distribution patterns and HOMO and LUMO orbitals ( ). In addition to these coordination modes, three other possible modes for 1:1 M:L stoichiometry (B', E and F) which have not been observed, also were optimized (). The result revealed that the thermodynamic stability of all modes is very similar. The percentage of coordination modes in  is consistent with this observation. The charge distribution patterns of the coordination modes proved that the charges on nitrogen and oxygen atoms of the ligand became more negative upon coordination. In all coordination modes, the LUMO is delocalized over the whole of ligand except nitrogen atom and methyl groups while the HOMO is delocalized on the metal center without any significant participation of the ligand molecule.

elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structures

Crystal structure of 1 

In the crystal structure of 1 ( ), the mercury atom is coordinated by one nitrogen and two oxygen atoms of MPC and two chloride ions giving a coordination number five. All coordination numbers of mercury(II) compounds in the CSD were studied (results in  ) and revealed that a coordination number four is common. The pentacoordinate geometry of 1 can adopt either a square pyramidal or a trigonal bipyramidal structure . To determine geometry of such structures, the formula of Addison et al.  was applied in which the angular structural parameter (τ) is represented as the index of trigonality. The parameter τ =(β - α)/60, where α and β are the two largest angles at the mercury atom with β  ⩾  α. An ideal square pyramid will have β =180° and α =180°, and therefore τ =0, but an ideal trigonal bipyramidal structure will have β =180° and α =120° and therefore τ =1 . The τ value here is calculated to be 0.57, closer to a trigonal bipyramidal than to square pyramidal geometry. All complexes of mercury(II) with a coordination number five in the CSD were studied in CSD to determine their coordination geometry by using the formula by Addison according to parameters of   which is suggested in this paper. The results () reveal that the most common geometry around the mercury(II) complexes with C.N=5 is the square pyramid.

The Hg<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Cl bond lengths are comparable with analogue structures (2.315<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) while the Hg<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Hg<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are shorter and longer than those of analogues (2.817 and 2.493<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), respectively . If the distortion in the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is disregarded, then the molecule has a <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>

A study of CSD structures revealed that the complex 1 is the first example of a compound containing a HgNpyO2Cl2 environment in which nitrogen and oxygen atoms are belonging to one ligand. The HgCl bond lengths are comparable with analogue structures (2.315Å) while the HgO and HgN bond lengths are shorter and longer than those of analogues (2.817 and 2.493Å), respectively . If the distortion in the crystal structure of 1 is disregarded, then the molecule has a C 2 axis and two σ v planes giving C 2v symmetry.

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 2 

In the crystal structure of 2 ( ), there are two cadmium atoms with different geometries. Cd1 with a coordination number nine has a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination environment. This structure is the 10th example of a cadmium complex with coordination number nine . Six sites are occupied by oxygen atoms of the carbonyl groups and three other sites are occupied by pyridine nitrogen atoms in which the CdO and CdN bond lengths are comparable with those of CSD average, 2.555 and 2.374Å, respectively. Three ligands which act as tridentate form six five-membered chelate rings with Cd1. If the distortion in the [CdL3]2+ unit is disregarded, with a C 3 axis and three perpendicular C 2 axes to the C 3 axis it has D 3 symmetry. A structural comparison between 2 and its isostructural congener (2')  showed that the space group is same (R3) and average bond lengths of CdN and CdO in 2 (2.330 and 2.550Å, respectively) are comparable with 2' (2.333 and 2.558Å, respectively). The distance between two cadmium ions in 2' (6.9508Å) is larger than in 2 (7.1821Å) which can be attributed to the high ionic radius of iodide ions.

elements.clean_text: Cd2 has a different environment with a coordination number four. The average of the four CdBr bond lengths is 2.597Å which is shorter than the CSD average (2.623Å). The tetracoordinate geometry of [CdBr4]2- can be either a tetrahedral or a square planar structure. To determine geometry of such structures, we propose a new formula in which the angular structural parameter (τ sq) is represented as the index of tetragonality. The parameter τ sq =(θ max - θ min)/90, where θ max and θ min are the maximum and minimum bond angles, respectively. An ideal square plane will have θ max =180° and θ min =90°, and therefore τ sq =1, but an ideal tetrahedron will have θ max =109.28°, θ min =109.28° and therefore τ sq =0. The τ sq value is calculated to be 0.01 for Cd2 indicating almost ideal tetrahedral geometry. All coordination numbers of cadmium(II) complexes in the CSD were studied ( ) and revealed that the coordination number six is most common. Also all complexes of cadmium(II) with coordination number four were examined to determine their geometry using our suggested formula with the parameters shown in  . The results () reveal that the most common geometry around cadmium(II) complexes with C.N=4 is incline to tetrahedron.

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). A literature survey of Cr(III)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>K(I) bridge revealed that there are two reported structures containing this motif . We have reported the same structure type with a different ligand and its crystallographic data were collected at different temperature (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) . The chromium atom, which is coordinated by four oxygen and two nitrogen atoms of two MPC ligands has a distorted octahedral geometry. Similarly to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the MPC acts as tridentate ligand in <ce:italic>mer</ce:italic> form  and the angle between mean planes of two coordinated ligands is 90.00°. The Cr<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are comparable with CSD average (1.960<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) while the Cr<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are shorter than those of analogous structures (2.080<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). All coordination numbers of chromium(III) complexes in the CSD were studied (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>) and revealed that the coordination number six is most common. The potassium(I) ion is eight-coordinated  by oxygen atoms from four carboxylic groups which form a dodecahedron around it (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>). Due to the bridging of O1 between Cr(III) and K(I) ions, the K1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O1 bond distance is significantly longer than that of the K1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O2 bond. A study of the literature revealed that there are no analogues containing four pairs of coordinated O<ce:inf loc="post">carboxylate</ce:inf> atoms to compare bond lengths and angles.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 3 

The crystal structure of 3 ( ) is a 2D s-d mixed-metal coordination polymer containing potassium(I) and chromium(III) through bridging of an oxygen atom of carboxylate groups between chromium(III) and potassium(I) ions ( ). A literature survey of Cr(III)OK(I) bridge revealed that there are two reported structures containing this motif . We have reported the same structure type with a different ligand and its crystallographic data were collected at different temperature (200K) . The chromium atom, which is coordinated by four oxygen and two nitrogen atoms of two MPC ligands has a distorted octahedral geometry. Similarly to 1 and 2, the MPC acts as tridentate ligand in mer form  and the angle between mean planes of two coordinated ligands is 90.00°. The CrO bond lengths are comparable with CSD average (1.960Å) while the CrN bond lengths are shorter than those of analogous structures (2.080Å). All coordination numbers of chromium(III) complexes in the CSD were studied ( ) and revealed that the coordination number six is most common. The potassium(I) ion is eight-coordinated  by oxygen atoms from four carboxylic groups which form a dodecahedron around it ( ). Due to the bridging of O1 between Cr(III) and K(I) ions, the K1O1 bond distance is significantly longer than that of the K1O2 bond. A study of the literature revealed that there are no analogues containing four pairs of coordinated Ocarboxylate atoms to compare bond lengths and angles.

In this way the oxygen atoms act as proton acceptors whereas the carbon atoms participate in hydrogen bonding as proton donors. The 2D coordination network is extended into the 3D by <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> stacking interactions between pyridine rings (centroid–centroid distance 3.503<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the angle between the planes 0°, the perpendicular distance between the planes 3.143<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the slippage 1.547<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st080">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">In this work, complexes of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (MPC) including [Hg(MPC)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd(MPC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][CdBr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and the coordination polymer of hydrolyzed MPC, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PDC), {K[Cr(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were synthesized and their spectral (IR, Raman, <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR), and structural properties were investigated. In the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2v</ce:inf> symmetry, the mercury atom is coordinated by one nitrogen and two oxygen atoms of MPC and two chloride ions and inclined to a trigonal bipyramidal geometry. A literature survey revealed that the most common geometry around mercury(II) complexes with C.N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5 is incline to square pyramidal. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has two cadmium atoms with different geometries including distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic and ideal tetrahedral. The statistic study of geometry around the cadmium(II) complexes with C.N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 using the new suggested formula revealed that common geometry is incline to tetrahedron. The chromium and potassium atoms in the coordination polymer of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have distorted octahedral and dodecahedral geometries, respectively. Coordination numbers of 4, 6, 6 were determined as common ones for mercury(II), cadmium(II) and chromium(III) ions from a CSD survey, respectively. All coordination modes of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate derivatives were compiled from CSD and optimized using Gaussian with Density Functional Theory (DFT). The computational results revealed that the thermodynamic stability of all modes is very similar, which is confirmed by experimental data. The charge distribution patterns of complexes revealed that the charge on nitrogen and oxygen atoms becomes more negative upon coordination to a metal.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, complexes of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate (MPC) including [Hg(MPC)Cl2] (1), [Cd(MPC)3][CdBr4] (2) and the coordination polymer of hydrolyzed MPC, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC), {K[Cr(PDC)2]}n (3) were synthesized and their spectral (IR, Raman, 1H NMR), and structural properties were investigated. In the crystal structure of 1 with C 2v symmetry, the mercury atom is coordinated by one nitrogen and two oxygen atoms of MPC and two chloride ions and inclined to a trigonal bipyramidal geometry. A literature survey revealed that the most common geometry around mercury(II) complexes with C.N=5 is incline to square pyramidal. The crystal structure of 2 has two cadmium atoms with different geometries including distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic and ideal tetrahedral. The statistic study of geometry around the cadmium(II) complexes with C.N=4 using the new suggested formula revealed that common geometry is incline to tetrahedron. The chromium and potassium atoms in the coordination polymer of 3 have distorted octahedral and dodecahedral geometries, respectively. Coordination numbers of 4, 6, 6 were determined as common ones for mercury(II), cadmium(II) and chromium(III) ions from a CSD survey, respectively. All coordination modes of dimethyl pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate derivatives were compiled from CSD and optimized using Gaussian with Density Functional Theory (DFT). The computational results revealed that the thermodynamic stability of all modes is very similar, which is confirmed by experimental data. The charge distribution patterns of complexes revealed that the charge on nitrogen and oxygen atoms becomes more negative upon coordination to a metal.

elements.clean_text:
Supplementary data

CCDC 1412846, 1412847 and 920815 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for complexes 1-3. These data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.poly.2015.10.038.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Hg(MPC)Cl2] (1)

0.19g (1.00mmol) of MPC dissolved in EtOH (10mL), was added with stirring to a solution of 0.27g (1.00mmol) of HgCl2 in EtOH (20mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 60°C for 5h. Colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained from the solution after standing for 5days. Yield: 0.41g, 88%; m. p. 158°C. Anal. Calc. for C9H9Cl2HgNO4 (466.67): C, 23.16; H, 1.94; N, 3.00. Found: C, 24.32; H, 2.05; N, 3.85%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3078m (ν CHar), 2947m (ν CH), 1724 s (ν CO), 1578m (ν CN), 1435m (δ as CH3), 1312 s (δ s CH3), 1257 v (ν CO), 748m and 694m (γ py). Raman (cm-1): 3071 w (ν CHar), 2980 w (ν CH), 1634m (ν CN), 678m (γ py), 506 w (ν HgN), 385m (ν HgO), 239m (ν HgCl). 1H NMR (300MHz, DMSO-d 6, ppm): δ =8.17-8.29 (m, 3 H, CHar), 3.91-3.92 (d, 6 H, CH).

Synthesis of [Cd(MPC)3][CdBr4] (2)

0.59g (3.00mmol) of MPC dissolved in MeOH (20mL), was added with stirring to a solution of 0.68g (2.00mmol) of CdBr2⋅4H2O in MeOH (20mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 60°C for 5h. Colorless crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained from the solution after standing for 3days. Yield: 0.44g, 78%; m. p. 183°C. Anal. Calc. for C27H27Br4Cd2N3O12 (1129.95): C, 28.70; H, 2.41; N, 3.72. Found: C, 30.03; H, 2.23; N, 4.27%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3086m (ν CHar), 2976m (ν CH), 1716 s (ν CO), 1596 s (ν CN), 1450m (δ as CH3), 1373m (δ s CH3), 1288m (ν CO), 764 w and 687 w (γ py). Raman (cm-1): 3040 w (ν CHar), 2946 w (ν CH), 1635m (ν CN), 1374 w (δ s CH3), 1296m (ν CO), 785 w and 684 w (γ py), 461 w (ν CdN), 338m (ν CdO), 131m (ν CdBr). 1H NMR (300MHz, DMSO-d 6, ppm): δ =8.20-8.47 (m, 3 H, CHar), 3.92-3.96 (d, 6 H, CH).

Synthesis of {K[Cr(PDC)2]} n  (3)

0.39g (2.00mmol) of MPC dissolved in EtOH (10mL), was added with stirring to a solution of 0.30g (1.00mmol) of K3[Cr(O2)4] in H2O (10mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 60°C for 5h. Light brown crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained from the solution after standing for a week. Yield: 0.22g, 53%; m. p.>300°C. Anal. Calc. for C14H6CrKN2O8 (421.31): C, 39.91; H, 1.44; N, 6.65. Found: C, 39.52; H, 1.68; N, 6.82%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3086m (ν CHar), 1715m (ν CO), 1618m (ν CN), 1452m (δ as CH3), 1379m (δ s CH3), 1281 v (ν CO), 741m and 694m (γ py). Raman (cm-1): 3024 w (ν CHar), 1696 s (ν CO), 1541m (ν CN), 1323m (ν CO), 739m (γ py), 617m (ν CrN), 461m (ν CrO), 304m (ν KO).

Table 7. The proposed parameters for determination of geometry around a metal with coordination number five. τ is calculated by the Addison formula.

| Geometry | τ Range |
|----------|--------|
| Ideal square pyramid | 0⩽τ⩾0.05 |
| Incline to square pyramid | 0.05<τ>0.5 |
| Intermediate structure | τ=0.5 |
| Incline to trigonal bipyramid | 0.5<τ>0.95 |
| Ideal trigonal bipyramid | 0.95⩽τ⩾1 |
